dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Back in 2019, Mark Zuckerberg just announced Facebook is abolishing political ads entirely.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Back in twenty nineteen, Mark Zuckerberg just announced Facebook is abolishing political ads entirely.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Twitter announced on Wednesday its intent to abolish political advertising on its platform, saying that political message reach should be earned, not bought. The announcement from Dorseys Twitter account came on the cusp of Facebooks scheduled third-quarter earnings call and after a month of relentless campaigning from Zuckerberg on the issue of political advertising and free speech.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and he's framing it as, uh, "political message reach should be earned, not bought." That's a pretty big shift.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and he's framing it as, uh, political message reach should be earned, not bought. That's a pretty big shift.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Twitter announced on Wednesday its intent to abolish political advertising on its platform, saying that political message reach should be earned, not bought.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and it comes after a month of Jack Dorsey really pushing this issue—like, he gave that speech at Georgetown University earlier this month arguing against paid political misinformation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and it comes after a month of Jack Dorsey really pushing this issue-like, he gave that speech at Georgetown University earlier this month arguing against paid political misinformation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: I dont think most people want to live in a world where you can only post things that tech companies judge to be 100% true, Zuckerberg said during a Georgetown University speech earlier this month.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Dorsey's point was basically, um, how can you say you're fighting misleading info but then let people pay to spread whatever they want in ads? He even threw in a wink at the end, which was kinda cheeky.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Dorsey's point was basically, um, how can you say you're fighting misleading info but then let people pay to spread whatever they want in ads? He even threw in a wink at the end, which was kinda cheeky.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Dorsey added a less veiled shot to the thread as well, noting it wouldnt be credible to say: Were working hard to stop people from gaming our systems to spread misleading info, buuut if someone pays us to target and force people to see their political ad well ... they can say whatever they want! Then, he added a wink.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and Zuckerberg fired back too—in that leaked audio from The Verge, he pointed out that Facebook's investment in safety is bigger than Twitter's entire revenue.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and Zuckerberg fired back too-in that leaked audio from The Verge, he pointed out that Facebook's investment in safety is bigger than Twitter's entire revenue.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On October 1, when The Verge published leaked audio from a Facebook company meeting, Zuckerberg mocks Twitter and its efforts to fix the health of their network. Our investment on safety is bigger than the whole revenue of their company.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oof, that's a burn. But it's interesting how they're both talking about the same problem—disinformation ahead of the 2020 election—but with totally opposite approaches.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oof, that's a burn. But it's interesting how they're both talking about the same problem-disinformation ahead of the twenty twenty election-but with totally opposite approaches.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The afternoon jousting added to a growing public spat between the two Internet moguls, both facing pressure to eliminate massive disinformation campaigns on their networks ahead of the 2020 general election.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. Zuckerberg says it's not about limiting free expression, it's about the ramifications of paying to amplify speech. But Dorsey thinks that stance has a major gap, like it's revisionist history.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. Zuckerberg says it's not about limiting free expression, it's about the ramifications of paying to amplify speech. But Dorsey thinks that stance has a major gap, like it's revisionist history.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This isnt about free expression, Dorsey said in a series of tweets. This is about paying for reach.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And yet, when asked about joining Facebook's Libra project, Dorsey was all "hell yes." So there's still some weird alliance potential there.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And yet, when asked about joining Facebook's Libra project, Dorsey was all hell yes. So there's still some weird alliance potential there.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When asked if he would join Facebooks Libra project, Dorsey had a simple answer: Hell, no.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. It's like they're allies on the big issue of regulation but completely at odds on how to execute it. Classic Silicon Valley drama.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. It's like they're allies on the big issue of regulation but completely at odds on how to execute it. Classic Silicon Valley drama.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Honestly though, the timing feels so critical—with the election coming up, the pressure on both of them is just immense.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Honestly though, the timing feels so critical-with the election coming up, the pressure on both of them is just immense.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The afternoon jousting added to a growing public spat between the two Internet moguls, both facing pressure to eliminate massive disinformation campaigns on their networks ahead of the 2020 general election.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: No kidding. And you can tell they're both trying to position their companies on the right side of history, but… from totally different angles.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No kidding. And you can tell they're both trying to position their companies on the right side of history, but... from totally different angles.

artist_script:
Back in 2019, Mark Zuckerberg just announced Facebook is abolishing political ads entirely.
HostB: Yeah, and he’s framing it as, uh, “political message reach should be earned, not bought.” That’s a pretty big shift.
HostA: Right, and it comes after a month of Jack Dorsey really pushing this issue—like, he gave that speech at Georgetown University earlier this month arguing against paid political misinformation.
HostB: Dorsey’s point was basically, um, how can you say you’re fighting misleading info but then let people pay to spread whatever they want in ads? He even threw in a wink at the end, which was kinda cheeky.
HostA: Yeah, and Zuckerberg fired back too—in that leaked audio from The Verge, he pointed out that Facebook’s investment in safety is bigger than Twitter’s entire revenue.
HostB: Oof, that’s a burn. But it’s interesting how they’re both talking about the same problem—disinformation ahead of the 2020 election—but with totally opposite approaches.
HostA: Exactly. Zuckerberg says it’s not about limiting free expression, it’s about the ramifications of paying to amplify speech. But Dorsey thinks that stance has a major gap, like it’s revisionist history.
HostB: And yet, when asked about joining Facebook’s Libra project, Dorsey was all “hell yes.” So there’s still some weird alliance potential there.
HostA: For sure. It’s like they’re allies on the big issue of regulation but completely at odds on how to execute it. Classic Silicon Valley drama.
HostB: Honestly though, the timing feels so critical—with the election coming up, the pressure on both of them is just immense.
HostA: No kidding. And you can tell they’re both trying to position their companies on the right side of history, but… from totally different angles.
